## [[quartoÂ®!!]{.quarto .bigger}](https://quarto.org/docs/guide/) (3 *types* of content):

::: {.columns .smaller}

::: {.column width="33%" .fragment .semi-fade-out fragment-index=1}
### [YAML](https://circleci.com/blog/what-is-yaml-a-beginner-s-guide/)

"executive" specs that control doc look & feel -- always located at very top:

```{yaml}                   
#| echo: true
---                    #<1>
title: "Mooseterpiece"
author: "I.M. Awesome"
format:
  revealjs:               #<2>
    mouse-wheel: true     #<2>
---
```
1. opening and closing fences indicated by 3 dashes (`---`)
2. indentations tend to be important (and finicky) within your {{< iconify devicon:yaml >}}

:::

::: {.column width="33%" .fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out fragment-index=1}
### Narrative

[**plain--text**]{.underline} (as you would specify on a notepad {{< iconify streamline-ultimate-color:paper-write>}}) with formatting indicated by [markdown](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html):

```
# 1^st^ level heading 

## 2^nd^ level Heading

this is **bold**
this is *italic*

```
:::


::: {.column width="34%" .fragment .fade-in fragment-index=2}

### Computations{#chunks}

isolated bits of code indicated with either one ([inline](https://quarto.org/docs/computations/inline-code.html)) or three ([code block](https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/html-code.html)) "ticks":

```{r}                   
#| echo: fenced

library(ggplot2)         #<1>

# Basic scatter plot    #<2>  
ggplot(mtcars, aes(
  x=wt, y=mpg)) + 
  geom_point()
```
1. any {{< iconify devicon:r >}} command you would normally specify within scripts or the console is valid within code chunks (including the loading of packages)
2. comments{{< iconify ant-design:comment-outlined >}} also operational within code chunks 

:::
